Expectation1: Respect the mentor's time and availability.
Situation1: The mentor has set aside open office hours throughout the week.
Expectation2: Deliver packages on time and to the correct address
Situation2: A medical supply delivery must reach a hospital department on schedule to ensure patient care
Story: I stared at my phone, the calendar app open, my thumb hovering over the time slot for Dr. Lee’s office hours. As her mentee, I knew how rare it was for her to have open hours, and she’d made it clear: “If you want to grow, show up. My time is limited.” I’d been preparing questions all week, eager to make the most of her availability. But just as I was about to leave, my work phone buzzed—a medical supply delivery, urgent, for the hospital’s cardiac unit. The package had to be there within the hour, no exceptions. I could picture the patients waiting, the nurses counting on me. My mentor’s words echoed in my mind, but so did the dispatcher’s: “Lives depend on this.” My heart pounded as I weighed the expectations—respect Dr. Lee’s time, or ensure the hospital got what it needed. I felt pulled in two, the pressure mounting, knowing I couldn’t be in both places at once.
